Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Population Genetics of Machu Picchu

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Inca citadel of Machu Picchu is an iconic landmark of human social history and technical endeavor. Built in the 15th century, Machu Picchu integrates refined architecture with dramatic landscape, and provides an archeological case study in understanding social centers of ceremony, politics, astronomy and agriculture. Although the site is among the most outstanding examples of human interaction with the natural environment, we know relatively little about the human component. This project uses genetic analyses to examine the biology and population dynamics of the people who lived and worked at Machu Picchu, and in doing so addresses questions in disciplines ranging from anthropology and history to evolutionary biology and environmental science. The project will also generate a wealth of genomic data for ancestral human populations, which will be a public resource for new avenues in genetic research and training. Moreover, given the status of Machu Picchu as an internationally recognized landmark and UNESCO World Heritage site, this project provides an ideal opportunity to engage wide audiences in human genetic history and archeological conservation. The project participants will conduct bilingual public seminars in the US and Peru to promote public understanding of human history and diversity. The project will also be integrated into parallel bilingual museum exhibits, further promoting longer-term international educational and research collaborations.

This project uses cutting-edge methods to sequence many types of ancient DNA (nuclear DNA, Y-chromosome, and mitochondrial DNA) to examine the genomes of people from throughout the Inca Empire. This includes the first comprehensive genetic analysis of the Machu Picchu skeletal remains from over 100 burials at the site. Genetic analyses of these individuals, and the biological relationships among them, will allow us to test many of the hypotheses surrounding this enigmatic site. These include questions regarding the functional role of Machu Picchu and its residents, and patterns of diversity, migration and labor diaspora in the Inca Empire. The investigators will compare the results of the genetic analysis with the previous archaeological, morphological and isotopic data from Machu Picchu, thus providing a more comprehensive understanding of the site and its socio-historical context. Understanding the population dynamics of the Inca Empire will in turn have broader impacts for understanding human genetic history and adaptation prior to European colonization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Machu Picchu is one of the world?s most recognizable archaeological site, inspiring researchers and the public imagination since its scientific discovery in 1911. The site, erected around the 1450s or 1460s, sits atop a ridge connecting two granite peaks in the Eastern Cordillera of the Peruvian Andes and overlooks the Urubamba River. Based on historic documents, masonry style and the analysis of ceramics, the construction of the site can be linked to the emperor Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui. On the upper slopes of Machu Picchu 107 burial caves, containing the remains of 177 distinct individuals, were found primarily concentrated in three main clusters, called Cemetery 1, 2 and 3.

The lack of historical documentation and the unusual characteristics of the site continue to stimulate numerous interpretations and questions with regards to the history and function of the site. Several hypotheses have been advanced ranging from Machu Picchu as a royal estate, sacred shrine, or provincial administrative center, all of these hypotheses strongly linked to speculations about the demographic composition and the regional origin of the buried. The aim of this project was to provide the first comprehensive genetic analysis of the Machu Picchu burial remains, along with several contemporaneous and pre-dating populations from the Central Andes, to get a better understanding of 1) demographic and population structure of the burial population; 2) the mode and impact of labor diaspora in the Inca Empire; 3) population genetics and biological diversity of the Cuzco region, the center of the Inca Empire, to reveal the function of Machu Picchu.

We were successful in obtaining genome-wide ancient DNA data from over 200 individuals, 40 of those from the Machu Picchu burial population. In the initial phase of the project we determined the genetic population structure of the pre-European Contact Andes, showing that we can genetically differentiate groups that inhabited different geographic regions in the past. This key effort, now allows us to determine the ancestral origin of those individuals buried at Machu Picchu. We find an extraordinary genetic diversity at Machu Picchu. Based on their genetics, individuals buried there share ancestry with groups all over the Andes, and even Amazonia, Ecuador, and Central Chile, showing that they derived from all regions of the Inca Empire and even beyond. This is in accord with previous archaeological observations, indicating diverse regions of origin for most of the buried based on grave goods and strontium isotopic rations. By combining the archaeological and genomic evidence we gain strong support for the hypothesis that the people buried at Machu Picchu were retainers that were brought to Machu Picchu from all over the Inca Empire and beyond to serve the Inca Elite. The individuals buried together in caves, were neither biologically related to each other, nor did they share common genetic ancestry, indicating that decisions on who was buried where, were rather opportunistic. By combining our genetic data with previously published isotopic data we could further determine that some individuals must have been first-generation immigrants, while others must have been offspring by parents of different genetic ancestry that grew up around Machu Picchu. This allows us new insights into the community structure of those that lived and served at Machu Picchu.  

The outcomes of this project significantly improve our understanding of Machu Picchu itself, but also deliver the first population biological information about the extent and impact of Inca relocation policies, and thus stands as a significant contribution to Andean archaeology. Further, the data generated here will allow future researchers to conduct more focused interdisciplinary studies addressing local population dynamics in the pre- and post- contact, and will prove valuable for other disciplines like evolutionary biology and medical genomics. The broader impacts of this project both affect the local communities in Peru, and communities in the US. Results have been disseminated in public talks, invited presentations to school children, and currently new museum exhibits are designed in Cusco and Lima, presenting the results in Quechua and Spanish. This also enhances critical local infrastructure while promoting sustainable tourism approaches. In the US the project used the exiting example of Machu Picchu to train young first-generation, mostly LatinX students in STEM relevant skillsets, while participating in revealing new insights into a key site in Native American and Latin American history.
